poems.title: Inside a Whisper
poems.author: Mason Lewis
poems.text:
Charge inside a whisper.
That is what I would do—
and bounce from sound to sound,
hearing dodgy, clattery
secrets that swerve
inside and out, and prance
from one atom to another.

Outside a whisper it is quiet,
like butterflies in a field,
while inside, it is a different world,
where creatures slouch and lounge,
hearing secrets so loud,
they have to deliver them
to the next person.
poems.bio: Mason Lewis, 12, is a 6th grader at the BioMed Science Academy.

poems.title: Dear Stress
poems.author: Lilac Secaur
poems.text:
You live in a sewer
with hands caked in crust and mud.
You smell of old fish,
rushed lies and decaying dreams.
You always pounce on the happiest of days.
You never leave the smallest mouthful
nor the gauntest crumb for other emotions to take.
Tell me, how you keep you dark green eyes
from glaring at yourself.
Your big bushy eyebrows and long gray beard
atop your spoiled milk yellow skin
are enough to make the clock run backwards.
Your glasses hint at disapproval atop your bumpy nose
With your top hat cane, and coat, you walk down the street
blind as all can see.
poems.bio:
Lila Secaur, 11, is a 6th grader at Stanton Middle School. She has been 
a member of the Wick Juniors Writing Club for four years. She has also taken part in the Wick workshops with the Palliative Care Unit at Akron Children‘s hospital.

poems.title: The Soccer Ball
poems.author: Mon Bahadur Subba
poems.text:
I had a torn soccer ball
that my mom gave me
when I was a child in Nepal.
I remember playing with friends
in the field near the jungle.
One time, suddenly, an elephant
came out from the jungle and we scattered.

I left my soccer ball in Nepal,
so I feel sad like I left my best friend.
I wish my soccer ball will be found
by my neighbors. so they can play
with it like I used to do.

Sometimes when I play soccer here,
I feel like I’m playing with my old ball
in the field near the jungle.
And I’m excited as if maybe
there is an elephant in Akron.
poems.bio: Mon Subba, a refugee from Nepal, came to the U.S. alone as a teenager. Mon did not have the opportunity to finish high school in Nepal, so he enrolled himself at Towpath High School upon arriving.

poems.title: Grace Note
poems.author: W.S. Merwin
poems.text:
It is at last any morning
not answering to a name
I wake before there is light
hearing once more that same
music without repetition
or beginning playing
away into itself
in silence like a wave
a unison in its own
key that I seem
to have heard before I
was listening but by the time
I hear it now it is gone
as when on a morning
alive with sunlight
almost at the year’s end
a feathered breath a bird
flies in at the open window
then vanishes leaving me
believing what I do not see
poems.bio: William Stanley Merwin is an American poet, credited with over fifty books of poetry, translation and prose. He has received two Pulitzer Prizes for poetry and was the United States Poet Laureate in 2010.

poems.title: My Pencil
poems.author: Ya Too
poems.text:
My pencil is a tree
that makes nature bloom on the paper.
My pencil digs up
the love of my parents’ life buried in my heart.
My pencil is the key
that opens the door to a new life.
My pencil is a rope
that ties the world together as one.
poems.bio: Ya Too, 13, is a 6th grader in Akron, Ohio. He was born in Thailand and now takes part in the Urban Vision after school program.

poems.title: Witness the River
poems.author: Jake Soyars
poems.text:
Witness the river,
the way it whispers ancient words
spoken by slithering streams
and vast oceans.

Witness the loneliness of the river,
how it longs for you,
but can’t quite reach you.

Witness the strange power
flowing through you,
traveling slowly
and brushing against your ankles—
something you can only feel
if you witness the river.

poems.title: Dear Monarch
poems.author: Mrs. Vesia’s Preschool Class
poems.text:
A caterpillar is so big,
so why are your wings so small?
Who painted your wings orange?
Fairies? Did they paint you all colors?

Your wings are pointed
and spotted, as if they’re shouting,
“You can’t eat me!”
to your predators.

What do you do inside your chrysalis?
Do you drink milk?
Do you sit on a little couch
with teeny pillows?

You get cold in the winter,
since you don’t have a tiny coat or boots.
So you spread your wings
like a superhero and fly to Mexico.

When you get there,
do you fold your wings
to make a dress
and go dancing?

poems.title: What I Have Inside Me
poems.author: Mary Wallace
poems.text:
I have a globe inside me
that tells me where to follow my dreams.
I have a sofa inside me
where all my feelings go and sit to calm down.
I have a sink inside of me
that washes away all my pain.
I have a cookie inside of me
that brings me happiness.
I have a spider
that eats away all hate.
I have a lamp inside of me
that lights me up when I’m down.
poems.bio: Mary Wallace, 11, is a 6th grader in Akron, Ohio. She was born in the United States and takes part in the Urban Vision after school program.

poems.title: Home
poems.author: Isabella Rodriguez
poems.text:
Suppose there is a city in the Buddha’s lap
and his knees are the mountains singing.

Suppose feathers rejoice when they fall
from an eagle’s wing, spinning and dancing.

Suppose nature is a map leading to willow trees
where spirits roam, speaking in old voices.

Suppose you can climb rocks like a billy goat
with clanking hooves and horns that curl for battle.

Suppose a path of dandelions and buttercups
takes you back to the mountain,

where you call out, “I’m home.”

poems.title: My Voice
poems.author: Hsa Ehser Byu
poems.text:
My voice is the key to my heart
I pull it out when I’m ready to unlock my words.
My voice is like the butterflies above my eyes
It wasn’t always colorful
It was blessed with power.
My voice is the map that guides me to my darkest secrets.
poems.bio: Hsa Ehser Byu, 12, is a 7th grader in Akron, born in Thailand. She now takes part in the Urban Vision after school program.

poems.title: Moon in the Window
poems.author: Dorianne Laux
poems.text:
I wish I could say I was the kind of child
who watched the moon from her window,
would turn toward it and wonder.
I never wondered. I read. Dark signs
that crawled toward the edge of the page.
It took me years to grow a heart
from paper and glue. All I had
was a flashlight, bright as the moon,
a white hole blazing beneath the sheets.
poems.bio: Dorianne Laux is an American poet. She has received fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts.

poems.title: Thank You, Tree
poems.author: Fatou M’Baye
poems.text:
Tree, you put the spark
back in my body.
And when I take a breath,
the lights behind my eyes
are turned on, and the fire
in my furnace crackles.
The whole world stops buzzing.

For once the Earth
will have a chance to think
and remember why we’re here.
On that day, I’ll look at you, tree,
through your leaves, your bark,
your sapwood, all the way to your heart—
your beating, beating heart—

and say, ”thank you.”
poems.bio: Fatou M’Baye, 13, is an 8th grader at Stanton Middle School. She spent three summers in the Wick Juniors Writing Camp.

poems.title: My Grandfather
poems.author: Dipan Chuwan
poems.text:
Hadjouba
who I grew up with
wearing suit and tie
took me to school
I wish he was here
poems.bio: Dipan Chuwan is a student at Jennings Middle School.

poems.title: My Heart
poems.author: Bo Mi
poems.text:
My heart is a colorful dress
that can attract people.

My heart is a neat dresser
that mends the clothes
I put in it.

My heart is sharp scissors
that can cut different
emotions into pieces.

My heart is a belt
that binds the feelings
of human beings.
poems.bio: Bo Mi is a member of Lisu people of Burma. In 2009, she relocated to Malaysia to escape violence in her city. She moved to Akron, Ohio and hopes to study of fashion at Kent State.

poems.title: The Soldiers in the Garden
poems.author: Martín Espada
poems.text:
After the coup,
the soldiers appeared
in Neruda’s garden one night,
raising lanterns to interrogate the trees,
cursing at the rocks that tripped them.
From the bedroom window
they could have been
the conquistadores of drowned galleons,
back from the sea to finish
plundering the coast.

The poet was dying;
cancer flashed through his body
and left him rolling in the bed to kill the flames.
Still, when the lieutenant stormed upstairs,
Neruda faced him and said:
There is only one danger for you here: poetry.
The lieutenant brought his helmet to his chest,
apologized to señor Neruda
and squeezed himself back down the stairs.
The lanterns dissolved one by one from the trees.

For thirty years
we have been searching
for another incantation
to make the soldiers
vanish from the garden.
poems.bio: Martín Espada is a Latino poet, and professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, where he teaches poetry.

poems.title: Remember
poems.author: Raina Smith
poems.text:
Remember your second house.
The cottage with the two doors and flickering light.
Remember the bunk beds which seemed calmer every night.
Remember the old fashioned wall light above the dresser.
Remember the chest of cars under the bed.
Remember the flower-coated trash can that always seemed to smile.
Stairs full of splinters and the dryer you could hear next door.
Remember the pencilless jars and the Nerf gun fights
you would always lose.
Remember the face-shaped windows that always seemed to smile.
Remember when you left that house and moved next door?
poems.bio:
Raina Smith, 13, is a 7th grader at Miller South School for Visual and
Performing Arts. She has been a member of the Wick Juniors Writing Camp for the past three summers.

poems.title: My Grandfather
poems.author: Luwella Esube
poems.text:
My grandfather
   whose stories were large
like a tree’s shadow
under which many people
could rest
   who walked slowly like a turtle
reflecting kindness
   who was over one hundred
and like a precious suitcase
contained wealthy things
   whose heart was open
like a flower
on which bees could land
to collect pollen
   whose voice was like honey
my grandfather
   whose life was a mirror to me
poems.bio: Luwela Esube, 42, is a refugee from the Democratic Republic of Congo. After fleeing the atrocities of the civil war in his country, Luwela spent 20 years in a refugee camp in Tanzania. He came to the U.S. with his wife and children in 2016 and resettled in Akron where he works at Akron’s Children's Hospital.

poems.title: You + I
poems.author: Tre’Vell Thomas
poems.text:
*For My Dad*

When I break like glass
   you fix me up again.
When I’m down
   you carry me.
I am a ball,
   and you’re the air in me
   making me bounce.
I am a bike,
   and you’re the chain
   spinning my wheels.
I am a kite,
   and you are the wind
   lifting me up.
poems.bio: Tre’Vell Thomas, 10, is a 5th grader in Akron, Ohio. He was born in the United States and takes part in the Urban Vision after school program.

poems.title: The Bracelet
poems.author: Linda Zhao
poems.text:
My grandmother gave me a brown bracelet
because I was going far away.
She slipped it off her tiny wrist and then reached for mine,
gently lifting it with her small, cold hands.
I look at an ugly bracelet with my 18 year old eyes,
as she slipped it onto my wrist,
and I thought, “I don’t want it.”
The magic is happening
in my heart.
I feel my grandmother wants
to go anywhere with me.
I can feel her great love
in the bracelet around my wrist.
Now, I look at my grandmother through my tears.
poems.bio: Linda Zhao is an immigrant from China. After being raised by her grandmother, she came to the US and became a permanent resident in 2015.

poems.title: You & I
poems.author: Linda Zhao
poems.text:
*For My Grandmother*

I am the growing grass,
and you are the nurturing dew
that kisses my blades in the morning.

I am the underground tunnel
and you are the famous archeologist
that discovered me
and brought me out of the dark.

I am the compass needle,
and you are the fully magnetic earth
that spins me
to point North.
poems.bio: Linda Zhao is an immigrant from China. After being raised by her grandmother, she came to the US and became a permanent resident in 2015.

poems.title: Where I’m From
poems.author: Mayada Iskandar
poems.text:
I am from paradise.
I am from the land
they call the “Swiss Middle East.”
I am from a town where I flee
and the mountains and the river
like a butterfly.
I am from the snow
the sun
and the wind
that give me life.
I am from the land that touches
my soul and my body.
I am from a worm house
built in love.
I am from the five senses
that keep me alive.
I am from a valley that
holds the life of my town.
I am from the mud that reminds me
I came from the soil.
I am from the natural food
comes from the heart of our ground.
poems.bio: Mayada Inskandar, 47, has been back and forth from Lebanon to the United States since 1991. She has lived here permanently since 2014 when she received a green card. Mayada now volunteers at an Adult Day Care in Youngstown, Ohio.

poems.title: D-Dude’s Story
poems.author: Dorian Utt
poems.text:
D Dude with his mohawk and orange mask,
green outfit and blue cape, has a hero’s voice.
Do you know his face can’t be revealed
to the villains, or they will catch him
and find where he lives?
D Dude uses his command remote
to drive his Dude mobile to the villains.
X Dude is trying to shrink D Dude’s muscles,
Mr. Smooth is making the ground slippery so he falls,
Mr. Crude is shouting, “you can’t walk, you’re never gonna walk.”
But D Dude wasn’t going to have any of that.
He uses his encouraging powers
to take their discouraging powers away
and that’s when they all turn back into regular kids:
Jimmy, John, and Joe.
And that’s when we learn never to be mean.
Now, with his super-mega powers,
he is ready to walk, just like his friend who made him.
poems.bio: Patient at Akron Children’s Hospital

poems.title: My Mother
poems.author: Usama Halak
poems.text:
Whose eyes were like the surface of a quiet sea
Whose words were like pure water irrigating thirsty fields

Whose advice gave clarity like eyeglasses
so I could see the right way

My mother whose face
was like a garden
Every time I looked at her
I rested among its fragrant flowers
poems.bio: Usama Halek, 53, is from Aleppo, Syria. For 12 years he was a political prisoner of the civil war in Syria. He escaped Syria and fled to Turkey and then Egypt, where he lived for 4 years. Usama arrived with his family in Akron in 2016. He has a Masters degree in Arabic Language and Literature.

poems.title: I am, You Are
poems.author: Thoo Lei Paw
poems.text:
I am a second valley and you are the flowing river in my heart
I am a lonely butterfly that always finds my way to see the beautiful garden
poems.bio: Thoo Lei Paw was born in Burma, resettled in a refugee camp in Thailand when she was two years old, and arrived in the U.S. with her husband in 2015.

poems.title: A Letter to Disconnect
poems.author: Kristin Wickless-Secaur
poems.text:
Your sultry sneakiness slithers in
while I busy myself seeking a louder life.
You dampen the sound
like tinny music through cheap speakers.
I go to brush you away, but my hand passes through you,
ethereal fog.
You cling to me, like moisture on my glasses,
fogging my view of the world.
I see all my days through you.
Tell me how you infiltrate,
infecting me like a virus clogging my joy,
chilling my clarity.
Tell me how you suck the light from all my spaces.
You rob me, even as you claim to keep me safe.
I have no tools to pry you loose.
How does one evict the air?
poems.bio:
Kristin Wickless-Secaur, 40, is a Pediatric ICU nurse at Akron Children’s Hospital.
She is a “Wick Mom” that has also been involved with the Wick Poetry Center through their involvement with Palliative Care Patients at Akron Children‘s of which her daughter, Lila, is one.

poems.title: Driving While Black
poems.author: Mwatabu S. Okantah
poems.text:
*From Muntu Kuntu Energy: New and Selected Poetry,*
Chatter House Press, 2013


*It is not what you call me,
it is what I answer to…
—African Proverb*

driving in my car
black wisdom from the ages is turned on its head:

in my car
what i think of my Self is of no significance
(save in my own mind…)
because i am always black while driving
and i know *they* are there   waiting   lurking
looking
out for some one black
like me.

i am a black man driving.
i have my own and countless other *blackmenintheircars*
stories to tell—
it is the same story; just new chapters from works in
progress
out of America’s deep black story well.

i am blessed.
i have driven through my youth
and into my elder years—
i am still driving. *they* are
still there watching.
sadly,
their *fears* are always near…
poems.bio:
Mwatabu S. Okantah holds a BA in English and African Studies from Kent State
University and the MA in Creative Writing from the City College of New York. He is an Associate Professor and Poet-in- Residence in the Department of Pan-African Studies at KSU and is the author of Afreeka Brass, Collage, and Legacy: for Martin & Malcolm among other works.

poems.title: My Hero
poems.author: Billy Collins
poems.text:
Just as the hare is zipping across the finish line,
the tortoise has stopped once again
by the roadside,
this time to stick out his neck
and nibble a bit of sweet grass,
unlike the previous time
when he was distracted
by a bee humming in the heart of a wildflower.
poems.bio: Billy Collins is an American poet and was appointed as Poet Laureate of the United States from 2001 to 2003.

poems.title: During a War
poems.author: Naomi Shihab Nye
poems.text:
For a moment I can’t
fold it up again—
where does “yours” end?
Dark eyes pleading what could we have done
differently?
Your family,
your community,
circle of earth, we did not want,
we tried to stop,
we were not heard
by dark eyes who are dying
now. How easily they
would have welcomed us in
for coffee, serving it
in a simple room
with a radiant rug.
Your friends and mine.
poems.bio: Naomi Shihab Nye, is a poet, songwriter, and novelist. She was born to a Palestinian father and an American mother. Although she calls herself a “wandering poet,” she refers to San Antonio as her home.

poems.title: First Journey
poems.author: Roger Craik
poems.text:
As inch by inch the train pulled out
with me inside alone,
I saw my mother in her Fifties skirt
and black-rimmed glasses and dark coat
watching still,
and then, as if to race the train,
my father running after me
not as an athlete would
or fathers of my friends at school,
but stroking, pressing down the air
with the heels of his hands and then with his palms
like some great cat with padded paws.

And all that afternoon through hours of fields
and towns whose names lodge with me still,
I saw him in my mind’s eye running thus
beyond the platform’s end and then beside the rails
on stony ground, on straggling grass,
outdistanced, and outdistanced further still.

poems.title: Ode To My Body
poems.author: Scott Parson’s 12th Grade Class
poems.text:
Bless the ear
a gateway for laughter
Bless the eyebrow
bushy with wisdom
Bless the foot
which gives equilibrium
to an unstable world
Bless the wrist
articulate as a spider
Bless the heart
how it beats even when broken
Bless the mouth
and its ocean of words
Bless the chest
the loudest drum of all
Bless the bellybutton
which is the scar of love.

poems.title: My Voice
poems.author: Danial Fasihdel
poems.text:
My voice is water
that washes dirty memories from my mind.

My voice is a pair of shoes
holding my feet on the difficult road ahead.

My voice is an umbrella that protects me
from the backbiting whispers of others.

My voice used to be an ash bin
of lies and deception, but now
it is an open treasure of truth and peace.
poems.bio: Danial Fasihdel, 29, is a refugee from Iran. After living in Turkey for over 3 years he was approved by the UN to move with his wife, Elmera, to Akron. They arrived in 2016 and Danial now works at the Gojo Company where he can apply his a degree in Industrial Management.

poems.title: Refuge
poems.author: Adam Khan
poems.text:
A book is refuge,
a friend I can talk to,
a home away from home.

A book is a doorway
to imagination, every page
a rushing river of words.

I read to see the world
from a different perspective,
to hide away in a secret corner
and create peace.
I read to carry on the story.
poems.bio: Adam Khan, 12, is a 6th grader at Stanton Middle School and has been a member of the Wick Juniors Writing Camp for the past 3 summers.

poems.title: My Voice
poems.author: Eli Mousavi
poems.text:
My voice is a boat that brought me
across a big sea.
My voice is a crib that holds me
as a child sleeps in her mother’s skirt.
My voice is a shiny sea
where I swim into my real dream.
My voice is a rope with strong knots
that tie me to my past.
My voice is a key that opens a door
to a bigger world.
poems.bio: Elmera Mousavi, 29, is a refugee from Iran. After living in Turkey for over 3 years she was approved by the UN to move with her husband, Danial, to Akron. Elmera has earned an Associates’ Degree in I.T. and now works at the Gojo Company.

poems.title: Driving
poems.author: Kate Daniels
poems.text:
That was the year that summer lingered
and fall came on late. I was still wearing
sleeveless clothes when the temperature fell,
and the wind rose suddenly, and tore the leaves
from their branches in a matter of days.
By then, there was a long line of addicts
on the corner every morning—red-nosed
and shivering, sores all over, reminding me
of the roaming packs of starving dogs you see
in third world countries. I shooed them away
when they begged for money... All that autumn,
I was searching for my son. Why I never looked
among the junkies on the corner who, after all,
were other people’s sons, or why—*god help me*—
I drove right through their tattered clots,
and kept my coins to myself, and controlled
my thoughts—I have no clue, I just kept driving
though I had no sense of where I was going,
or what I’d do, or what I might find if I got there.
poems.bio: Kate Daniels is an American poet and is a poetry professor at Vanderbilt University.

poems.title: My Soul
poems.author: Desman Tucker
poems.text:
My soul is a white sock in a dryer
surrounded by everyone else’s colored socks
My soul is different
My soul is a bird that fell out of the nest
My soul wants to explore
Maybe I should let it go and fly away
poems.bio: Desman Tucker, 13, is a 7th grader in Akron, Ohio. He takes part in the Urban Vision after school program.

poems.title: I Want to Be
poems.author: Richa Gajmer
poems.text:
I want to be a pencil
so that people can write notes to each other.
I want to be a shell
so that I can be safe and the sharks don’t eat me.
I want to be a singer
so that I can sing beautiful songs.
I want to be an umbrella
so that I don’t get wet.
I want to be a wind
so that people can smell the air.
poems.bio: Richa Gajmer, 9, is a 4th grader in Akron, Ohio who previously took part in the Urban Vision after school program.

poems.title: A Winter Sunset
poems.author: Ted Kooser
poems.text:
At the foot of the hill,
the trees have pulled on
boots of shadow. Where,
I ask them, do they think
they’re going “Round
the world,” they answer,
“back by morning.”
poems.bio: Ted Kooser is an American poet. He served as Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress from 2004 to 2006.

poems.title: Along the Trail
poems.author: Adam Khan
poems.text:
*Cuyahoga Valley National Park*

Along the trail, walking slowly,
is where my ideas flow.

Along the trail, walking slowly,
is where I can think.

Along the trail, walking slowly,
is where I feel free.

Along the trail, walking slowly,
is where I feel safe.

Along the trail, walking slowly,
is where I flourish.

Along the trail, walking slowly,
is where I learn.

Along the trail, walking slowly
is where I feel at home.
poems.bio: Adam Khan, 12, is a 6th grader at Stanton Middle School and has been a member of the Wick Juniors Writing Camp for the past 3 summers.

poems.title: My Heart
poems.author: Luwella Esube
poems.text:
My heart is a golden helmet.
It warns me about future accidents
with other people.
My heart is a gracious belt.
It reaches out to fasten my enemies
and bring them closer to me.
My heart is a comb
that can reset my bad feelings.
My heart reflects my life
like a public mirror.
My children can follow my teaching
by looking into my heart.
poems.bio: Luwela Esube, 42, is a refugee from the Democratic Republic of Congo. After fleeing the attrocities of the civil war in his country, Luwela spent 20 years in a refugee camp in Tanzania. He came to the U.S. with his wife and children in 2016 and resettled in Akron where he works at Akron's Children's Hospital.

poems.title: Testimonial
poems.author: Rita Dove
poems.text:
Back when the earth was new
and heaven just a whisper,
back when the names of things
hadn’t had time to stick;

back when the smallest breezes
melted the summer into autumn,
when all the poplars quivered
sweetly in rank and file…

the world called, and I answered.
Each glance ignited to a gaze.
I caught my breath and called that life,
swooned between spoonfuls of lemon sorbet.

I was pirouette and flourish,
I was filigree and flame.
How could I count my blessings
when I didn’t know their names?

Back when everything was still to come,
luck leaked out everywhere.
I gave my promise to the world,
and the world followed me here.
poems.bio: Rita Frances Dove is an American poet and essayist. From 1993 to 1995, she served as Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress.

poems.title: My Heart
poems.author: Usama Halak
poems.text:
I am the cold body
and you are the woolen coat
which makes me warm.
I am the rider of the bicycle
and you are the helmet
which protects my head if I fall down.
I am the dark room
and you are the
classic lamp which lights my heart.
I am the dark night
and you are the light of the room
which sneaks through the windows
of my life.
poems.bio: Usama Halek, 53, is from Aleppo, Syria. For 12 years he was a political prisoner of the civil war in Syria. He escaped Syria and fled to Turkey and then Egypt, where he lived for 4 years. Usama arrived with his family in Akron in 2016. He has a Masters degree in Arabic Language and Literature.

poems.title: If I Were
poems.author: Nadia Anwaar
poems.text:
If I were a flower, 
I would sprinkle my colors 
to a black and white world,
like a make-up to a woman 
who just woke up.

If I were a snowflake,
I would dive into the earth
and cover it with my coldness.

If I were a window, 
I would let people see through me 
to tell them how beautiful 
the world is.
poems.bio: Nadia Anwaar is a sixth grader at Jennings Middle School. She is eleven years old.

poems.title: Recovery
poems.author: Dustin Kosley
poems.text:
Recovery is like a caterpillar
evolving into a beautiful creature.
Or like a spider that crawls up
a down spout
and gets knocked back to the beginning,
only to continue upward
refusing to give in!

Doors open and a whole new life emerges.
From your past doors close,
letting out light from its cracks,
so it may be remembered.

Recovery is not easy.
It demands discipline and understanding
continuous attention, and reflection.
A requirement of hope.

Recovery needs hard work and strength,
like building a home
with brick and mortar
mending.

Recovery is discovery.
You are an explorer
finding yourself in a new land.

Recovery is one minute, one day,
one week at a time.
It works if you work it.

poems.title: Superhero
poems.author: Day Soe Wah
poems.text:
My superhero can’t save all lives.
My superhero can’t dodge bullets or knives.
My superhero can’t fight bad people.
My superhero can’t fight against evil.
My superhero does not have any powers.
My superhero can’t fly over towers.
But what he can do is love me.
He can work hard and do his job for me.
My superhero is my dad.
poems.bio: Day Soe Wah, 11, is a 6th grader in Akron. She is the daughter of immigrants and takes part in the Urban Vision after school program.

poems.title: My Heart
poems.author: Yanquin Weng
poems.text:
My heart is a box of bright crayons
that can draw my rich imagination
and my multi-colored life.

My heart is like foggy glasses.
I can’t see the world
as clearly as I would like to.

My heart is like a pair of dancing shoes
that can take my soul to any destination
and spin with the scenery.

My heart is a natural clock.
I wish I could turn its hands
back to the past
to spend more time with my mom.
poems.bio: Yanqin Wen immigrated to the United States from China in 2009. In China she was a kindergarten teacher. She now works as a cashier at a restaurant while she takes lessons to improve her English.

poems.title: Colors
poems.author: Rachel Dim Ra
poems.text:
Red is a pencil that can tell the story of my thoughts.
It keeps me drawing.
Yellow is a clock that wakes me up
when the sun touches my face.
White is my mother’s smile
bright and shiny like a candle in my life.
poems.bio:
Rachel Dim Ra is a refugee from Burma. She resettled in Malaysia, but upon entering
the country, she was not given her passport back. She was arrested, and after nine days
in immigration and a large fine, she received her UN card. She lived in Malaysia for eight
years before coming to the United States in July of 2016.

poems.title: What I Want
poems.author: Shauna Oldaker
poems.text:
I want to burn the pages of hate.

I want to feel a waterfall
run down my back.

I want to find a vaccine
for pain and suffering in the human soul.

I want the
He saids and She saids
to be,
We all said!

I want gossip to shrivel
up into a ball
so I can kick it around
with my cleats

poems.title: My Voice
poems.author: Mrs. Galambos’ 4th Grade Class
poems.text:
My voice fills the air
with song.
It pops out like a purple crocus in spring,
blooming louder every day.

My voice carries a secret
then passes it on.

My voice is like an oven—it dings
when a great idea is done.

My voice moves
to the vibrations
of peace.

I hear the world sing
and my voice sings back.

poems.title: Soldier’s Heart
poems.author: Maj Ragain
poems.text:
We sing the old wounds,
word by word, stitch by stitch,

many hands, many voices.
The needle hurts as the thread

is drawn through, the mouth
of the wound drawn shut.

Our work is to listen hard,
to look the wounded in the eye,

to stitch and pull
press through pain,

until every knot is tied,
every last wound closed,

every broken heart
healed and whole.

poems.title: My Mother’s Name is Lucha
poems.author: Juan Felipe Herrera
poems.text:
your hands my hands
kindnesses  dances  silences sitting     you  i
     El Paso   Texas Segundo Barrio
Juarez 1918 1936 in gypsy   dress actress
you sing     i sing we sing     lullabies of old
this     now lines now     my birth
heart now life
                              all life     now
         i bow                    to you
poems.bio: Juan Felipe Herrera was the 21st Poet Laureate of  the United States and is the first Latino  to hold the position. Herrera’s many collections of poetry include Notes on the Assemblage; Senegal Taxi; and Half of the World in Light: New and Selected Poems. Herrera is also a performance artist and activist on behalf of migrant and indigenous communities and at-risk youth.
